occurrences.line_text: Sir Brianor, so sore, that none him life behote.
And as her life by her esteemed deare.
Ne in his face or bloud or life appeard,
Death is to him, that wretched life doth lead,
That liues a loathed life, and wishing cannot die.
She ran in hast his life to haue bereft:
In all his life, which afterwards he lad,
Or selfe disliked life doth thee thus wretched make?
Of life it be, then better doe aduise.
And make me loath this life, still longing for to die.
An happie life with grace and good accord,
The whiles his life ran foorth in bloudie streame,
And eke too loose of life, and eke of loue too light.
For whose sole libertie I loue and life did stake.
Of all her land and lordship during life:
Druons delight was all in single life,
I wast my life, and doe my daies deuowre
I neither can my loue, ne yet my life forgo.
And louers life forth set.
And wish to life return'd againe to bee,
With which that wretched Greeke, that life forlore
In languor wastes his life:
And greedy seas doe in the spoile of life delight.
But if that life ye vnto me decree,
And deeme vnworthy or of loue or life,
In which his life vnluckily was layd,
Or loue forbid him, that is life denayd:
To graunt to her, her sonnes life, which his foe
True loue despiseth shame, when life is cald in dread.
The fortune of her life long time did feare.
Now by my life (sayd he) and God to guide,
Twixt life and death, long to and fro she weaued,
Which to her in that daunger hope of life did offer.
For any death to chaunge life though most bad:
Who more then losse of life ydreaded it;
Then lead that shamefull life, vnworthy of a Knight.
That all that while her life she safely garded:
In sencelesse swoune, as if her life forsooke,
That might haue had of life or death election:
To thrall my looser life, or my last bale to breed.
Doth not your handmayds life at your foot lie?
For lending life to me a wretch vnkind;
Through which she might his wretched life bereaue.
Chiefely by him, whose life her law doth bynd,
Whose life did lie in her least eye-lids fall;
Life, freedome, grace, and gifts of great auaile,
Whose life and manners straunge she neuer knew;
My life now to, for which a little whyle
Of life: for he was nothing valorous,
And continence of life, that all forgon,
And tell him for his sake thy life thou gauest.
(Sayd she) yet now I gin new life to feele,
To whom nought else, but bare life doth remaine,
Is liker lingring death, then loathed life to bee.
And life enioy for any composition.
And powred forth his wretched life in deadly dreare.
It often fals in course of common life,
That earst was dead, restor'd to life againe,
Who her imprisond hath, and her life often sought.
Then thus replide; Now sure and by my life,
Though I this dearest life for her doe spend;
Fro dangers dread his doubtfull life to saue;
Of those, which sought his life for to empaire.
Dearer is loue then life, and fame then gold;
And new life to her lent, in midst of deadly feare.
In all her life, with long nayles ouer raught,
But that some life remayned secretly,
Into the life of his malignant foe;
But saue my life, which lot before your foot doth lay.
I will it graunt, your hopelesse life to saue;
By which he had to her both life and loue restord.
Twixt life and death, not knowing what was donne.
For first, next after life, he tendered her good.
And wretched life forlorne for vengement of his theft.
His life attonce; who nought could do, but shun
He saw his life powrd forth dispiteously:
Would streight dislodge the wretched wearie life.
Therein the Hermite, which his life here led
As one that had no life him left through former feare.
That euer I this life vnto thee lent,
Yet since thy life vnto this Ladie fayre
And onely suffred him this wretched life to liue.
To whom his life he graunted for her loue,
He of the Prince his life receiued late,
Great treason to him meant, his life to reaue.
The Prince soone hearkned, and his life forgaue.
He glad of life, and willing eke to wreake
So hard a taske, as life for hyre to sell;
I yearned haue, that life so dearely did redeeme.
That recreant knight, whose hated life I sought?
That for his sake his deare life had forgone;
Plaine signes in him of life and liuelihead.
And how that he in lieu of life him lent,
Hauing subdew'd, yet did to life restore,)
My life will by his death haue lamentable end.
Great perill of his life, and restlesse paines did take.
Readie to launce her brest, and let out loued life.
For her did languish, and his deare life spend;
Gan highly to commend the happie life,
Leading a life so free and fortunate,
This lowly quiet life, which I inherite here.
Of life, which here in lowlinesse ye lead,
Sith each vnto himselfe his life may fortunize.
This simple sort of life, that shepheards lead,
His life he steemed dearer then his frend.
Her wretched life, shut vp in deadly shade,
They found that life did yet in her remaine:
That they to life recouered her at last.
How he might saue her life, if life did last;
How he might saue her life, if life did last;
And life to feele, that long for death had sought;
Departed life, and left vnto them all.
Did languish long in lifeconsuming smart,
His greedy flames, and kindled life-deuouring fire.
Against this lifelesse shadow so to fight:
But finding no fit seat, the lifelesse corse it left.
That like a lifelesse corse immoueable he stood.
Where when he saw his fellow lifelesse ly,
Nor life-resembling pencill it can paint,
For lifes succession in those brethren three.
Was forst to seeke my lifes deare patronesse:
And of my lifes deare loue beloued be:
Weening her lifes last howre then neare to bee,
Him thus bespake; My liefe, my lifes desire,
Of forreine helpes to lifes due nourishment:
My lifest Lord she thus beguiled had;
Is cal'de Blacke water, and the Liffar deep,
There was the Liffy rolling downe the lea,
Lifht goote Cymothoe, and sweete Melite,
At last she vp gan lift: with trembling cheare
Did grone, as feeble so great load to lift;
And ouer them Arachne high did lift
And lift it selfe vnto the highest skies?
Ouer the waues his rugged armes doth lift,
Sometimes the one would lift the other quight
Th'embroderd quilt she lightly vp did lift,
He vp gan lift toward the azure skies,
When so he list in wrath lift vp his steely brand.
Vnlesse the heauens them lift to lawfull soueraintie.
That quite smit off his arme, as he it vp did lift.
That pride doe not to tyranny you lift;
High lifted vp were many loftie towres,
He lifted vp his hand, that backe againe did start.
Himselfe vp high he lifted from the ground,
In his light wings, is lifted vp to skye:
And lifted high aboue this earthly masse,
Through whose bright ventayle lifted vp on hye
And lifted vp to honorable place,
Liftes vp his head, that did before decline
Lifteth it vp, that else would lowly fall:
And lifting vp his lompish head, with blame
And lifting vp his dreadfull club on hight,
Lifting to heauen her euerlasting fame:
Who lifting vp his head, him answerd thus:
Tho lifting vp his vertuous staffe on hye,
His limbes would rest, ne lig in ease embost,
Great Lady of the greatest Isle, whose light
Did spred so broad, that heauens light did hide,
Vertue giues her selfe light, through darkenesse for to wade.
A litle glooming light, much like a shade,
Soone as that vncouth light vpon them shone,
For light she hated as the deadly bale,
Of highest God, the Lord of life and light;
Remounted vp as light as chearefull Larke,
Much grieu'd to thinke that gentle Dame so light,
But firme is fixt, and sendeth light from farre
Had spent his lampe, and brought forth dawning light,
All night she thinks too long, and often lookes for light.
That should as death vnto my deare hart light:
But welcome now my light, and shining lampe of blis.
Beares her away vpon his courser light:
Through light misdeeming of her loialtie,
Her glorious glitterand light doth all mens eyes amaze.
And to my loathed life now shewes some light,
Still did he wake, and still did watch for dawning light.
That from their shields forth flyeth firie light,
That shyning lampes in Ioues high house were light:
And th'vnacquainted light began to feare:
And can the children of faire light deface.
But early rose, and ere that dawning light
Why do ye lenger feed on loathed light,
Like glauncing light of Phoebus brightest ray;
He could not rearen vp againe so light,
The light whereof, that heauens light did pas,
The light whereof, that heauens light did pas,
As where th'Almighties lightning brond does light,
His pined corse, him scarse to light could beare,
Of fowle Duessa, when her borrowed light
Into this world, and shewed heauens light,
As time in her iust terme the truth to light should bring.
O fairest virgin, full of heauenly light,
That wofull louer, loathing lenger light,
And round about her head did shine like heauens light.
And opened his dull eyes, that light mote in them shine.
That he his paine endur'd, as seeming now more light.
Those glistring armes, that heauen with light did fill,
The wrathfull beast about him turned light,
And left not any marke, where it did light;
Vpon the ioynt the lucky steele did light,
Huge flames, that dimmed all the heauens light,
When morning deaw vpon their leaues doth light:
And to the world does bring long wished light;
And glorious light of her sunshyny face
At which the bushy Teade a groome did light,
And light this wearie vessell of her lode.
In couert vele, and wrap in shadowes light,
But would be dazled with exceeding light.
Where so he be, and soone vpon him light.
And take away this long lent loathed light:
She groueling threw to ground, as hating life and light.
Vplifted light, and softly did vphold:
Full of disport, still laughing, loosely light,
Cleare the deawy ayre with springing light,
Purloynd both steed and speare, and ran away full light.
In his light wings, is lifted vp to skye:
At his commaund, and reared him vp light
Kindled aboue at th'heauenly makers light,
Gan burne in filthy lust, and leaping light,
Where this same wicked villein did me light vpon.
That it should not deface all others lesser light?
Great cause, that carries thee so swift and light.
Their wanton follies, and light meriment;
To laugh at shaking of the leaues light,
Her light behauiour, and loose dalliaunce
And vaine delight she saw he light did pas,
What dismall day hath lent this cursed light,
That now I weene Ioues dreaded thunder light
The faithfull light of that faire lampe yblent,
Couer'd with boughes & shrubs from heauens light,
But a faint shadow of vncertain light;
More light then Culuer in the Faulcons fist.
That with their brightnesse made that darknesse light,
But that this darksome neather world her light
So backe againe, him brought to liuing light.
With that all desperate as loathing light,
And with her light the earth enlumines cleare;
Now hath the Sunne with his lamp-burning light,
The Prince by chaunce did on a Lady light,
Therein gaue light, and flam'd continually:
Whence all that liues, does borrow life and light,
The light goes out, and weeke is throwne away;
And soone againe as he his light withhault,
Which do that sence besiege with light illusions.
Vpon his head he wore an Helmet light,
Vpon the waues to spred her trembling light,
And the light bubbles daunced all along,
From the departing land it launched light,
Her to rebuke, for being loose and light:
And eke the gate was wrought of substaunce light,
That euer mixt their song with light licentious toyes.
And oft inclining downe with kisses light,
Fraile harts, yet quenched not; like starry light
His Cynthia, his heauens fairest light?
Which by her owne law to your lot doth light,
Did sparckle forth great light, and glorious did appeare.
Where she may find the substaunce thin and light,
With which faire Britomart gaue light vnto the day.
And to faire semblaunce doth light faith annexe;
Her loue too light, to wooe a wandring guest:
Doth light the lower world, were halfe yspent,
Eftsoones long waxen torches weren light,
That bodie, wheresoeuer that it light,
Now haue three Moones with borrow'd brothers light,
Tho to their ready Steeds they clombe full light,
Her Helmet, to her Courser mounting light:
To light their blessed lamps in Ioues eternall hous.
And that perforce, for want of lenger light,
With their light wings, the sights of semblants vaine:
And light doe shonne, for feare of being shent:
For light ylike is loth'd of them and thee,
And all that lewdnesse loue, doe hate the light to see.
And bring with him his long expected light?
And fro me reft both life and light attone.
The wicked steele stayd not, till it did light
And from his head his heauy burganet did light.
That hast from darkenesse me returnd to light,
To blot her honour, and her heauenly light.
Deeme of her high desert, or seeme so light:
Adorne the world with like to heauenly light,
Is rightly cald, th'author of life and light;
Who for some light displeasure, which him crost,
And were with sweet Ambrosia all besprinckled light.
A litle smoke, whose vapour thin and light,
But made her selfe more light, away to fly:
Coyly rebutted his embracement light;
But she thereto would lend but light regard,
He it dissembled well, and light seem'd to esteeme.
Which with rare light his bote did beautifie,
Both light of heauen, and strength of men relate:
The shyning glory of your soueraigne light,
To dry them selues by Vulcanes flaming light,
That in a cloud their light did long time stay,
From aged Mnemon; for my wits bene light.
Bewrayed had the world with early light,
And all the passions, that in man may light,
And th'other all yclad in garments light,
He vp remounted light, and after faind to wend.
Vpon his hands and feete he crept full light,
Early before the heauens fairest light
That on the rockes he fell so flit and light,
But chaunced on a craggy cliff to light;
Tho stooping downe she him amoued light;
Of massy gold, which with his owne light shone;
As those same plumes, so seemd he vaine and light,
In silken samite she was light arayd,
But the stout Damzell to him leaping light,
Soone as he heard, himself he reared light from ground.
Is creasted all with lines of firie light,
That still are led with euery light report.
Ne for light Ladies loue, that soone is lost.
And mounting light his foe for lying long vpbrayes.
Which when as Blandamour, whose fancie light
Sometimes him blessing with a light eye-glance,
So soone as heauens window shewed light,
His dreadfull souse auoydes, it shunning light,
All suddenly they both vpstarted light,
Whom he that hath, were loth to lose so light,
Till by mishap he in his foemens hand did light.
That daz'd the eyes of all, as with exceeding light.
Compar'd to her, that shone as Phebes light,
Ne her owne Amoret forgoe so light
For he their words as wind esteemed light.
But comfort take: for by this heauens light
But ouerleapes them all, like Robucke light,
But that he was full light and nimble on the land.
That any little blow on her did light,
To come and shew themselues before the light,
He seeing her depart, arose vp light,
That both his iuell he had lost so light,
Ye may redresse, and me restore to light.
These gentle Ladies will misdeeme too light,
Did shun the proofe thereof and it auoyded light.
And eke too loose of life, and eke of loue too light.
By fortune in that place did chance to light:
Shyning with beauties light, and heauenly vertues grace.
Light Doto, wanton Glauce, and Galene glad.
Euagore, and light Pontoporea,
Ne is that same great glorious lampe of light,
But wheresoeuer it did light, it throughly shard.
His yron page, who him pursew'd so light,
And you, Sir Knight, that loue so light esteeme,
Or weigh the light, that in the East doth rise;
That he of little things made reckoning light,
Wroth wext he then, and sayd, that words were light,
The second day, so soone as morrow light
And both adorn'd with lampes of flaming light,
She chaunst vnwares to light vppon this coffer,
And him restoring vnto liuing light,
All in a Camis light of purple silke
Which was short tucked for light motion
Doth seeme to be her selfe, though darkned be her light.
For yeelding to a straungers loue so light,
Now seeking darkenesse, and now seeking light;
Of things abrode, as next to hand did light,
And many things demaund, to which she answer'd light.
Discouered had the light to liuing eye,
But tooke her steede, and thereon mounting light,
And from her eies did flash out fiery light,
As when the flashing Leuin haps to light
And ioyous light the house of Ioue forsooke:
The morrow next, so soone as dawning light
The vaile, which did his powrefull light empeach;
So light of hand, and nymble of his pace,
To thinke to follow him, that was so swift and light.
Yet would not let iust vengeance on her light;
Few perling drops from her faire lampes of light;
And bringing light into the heauens fayre,
Nor where it light, but gan to chaufe and sweat,
Vntill late mischiefe did vppon me light,
Yet not so hard (for nought so hard may light,
Whose goodly light then Phebus lampe doth shine more cleare?
His chearefull face, and light to men restore,
The morrow next, before the lampe of light,
But Calidore vprose againe full light,
Preuented him before his stroke could light,
And leaping to him light, would haue vnlast
Gan reare her eyes as to the chearefull light,
But now weake age had dimd his candle light.
That he so rudely did vppon them light,
Who was more light of foote and swift in chace,
Twixt darkenesse dread, and hope of liuing light,
Now wanting them he felt himselfe so light,
Till that the morning, bringing earely light
Inflicts with dint of sword, so sore doth light,
That him too light of credence did mislead,
Like a fell Lyon leaped to him light,
Dismounting light, his shield about him threw,
But wayt aduantage, when they downe did light.
For being of his loue to her so light,
And had he not vpon him fallen light,
Of courtly fauour, fed with light report,
Or else to course about their bases light;
All other lesser lights in light excell,
Her louely light was dimmed and decayd,
Yet did the cloud make euen that dimmed light
So there all day they bode, till light the sky forsooke.
With noyse whereof the theefe awaking light,
With which he forth went into th'open light:
And forth her bringing to the ioyous light,
She forth gan lay vnto the open light
At length into a Monastere did light,
For aye in darkenesse, which day light doth shonne:
Then it had lighted on an aged Oke;
She from her palfrey lighted on the plaine,
She bad to lighten my too heauie band,
That all the earth doest lighten with thy rayes,
Like lightening flash, that hath the gazer burned,
No more then lightening from the lofty sky.
With lighter hearts vnto their home retird;
For him so far had borne his light-foot steede,
And all the troupe of light-foot Naiades,
The light-foot Squire her quickly turnd around,
And farre before a light-foot Page did flie,
His light-foot beast, fled fast away for feare:
There she alighted from her light-foot beast,
Who from them fled, as light-foot hare from vew
And lighting on his horses head, him quite did mall.
And lighting candles new, gan search anone,
Dismounting lightly from his loftie steed,
Least thou of her beleeue too lightly blame,
The knight her lightly reared vp againe,
Vpstarted lightly from his looser make,
And lightly lept from vnderneath the blow:
And lightly leaping from so monstrous maine,
She lightly sprinkled on his weaker parts;
He lightly left the foe, with whom he fought,
The knight then lightly leaping to the pray,
Both horse and man vp lightly rose againe,
From loathed soile he can him lightly reare,
He lightly snatcht, and did the floudgate stop
An heauie load himselfe did lightly reare,
His grasping hold: so lightly did vpstart,
But lightly shunned it, and passing by,
Did lightly leape, where he them bound did see,
And lightly mounted, passeth on his way,
The which on the dull waues did lightly flote
But Guyon lightly to him leaping, stayd
Sir Guyons sword he lightly to him raught,
Vpon him lightly leaping without heed,
But ground he gaue, and lightly leapt areare:
At need, till now, he lightly threw away,
His falsed faith, and loue too lightly flit,
Of scorched deaw, do not in th'aire more lightly flee.
Would not so lightly follow beauties chace,
Lightly arose out of her wearie bed,
Th'embroderd quilt she lightly vp did lift,
She lightly lept out of her filed bed,
But lightly rased her soft silken skin,
No idle charmes so lightly may remoue,
But Timias him lightly ouerhent,
Lightly vpstarted from the dustie ground,
Lightly she leaped, as a wight forlore,
Hurling his sword away, he lightly lept
She lightly vnto him adioyned side to syde;
And hauing her from Trompart lightly reard,
Or loosenesse, that she lightly did remoue.
But let him passe as lightly, as he came:
Lightly he clipt her twixt his armes twaine,
By meanes whereof he hath him lightly ouerborne.
She litle answer'd him, but lightly did aggrate.
Full lightly, ere himselfe he could recower,
He lightly lept out of his place of rest,
They lightly her requit (for small delight
Shee smote them lightly with her powrefull wand.
They vp againe them selues can lightly reare,
Lightly Cambello leapt downe from his steed,
And lightly issewd forth to take his lot.
And lightly started vp as one affrayd;
With so fell rage, her selfe she lightly gan
Lightly he started vp out of that stound,
But after her full lightly he vprose,
And flew away, as lightly as the wind:
Whose looser thought will lightly be misled,
Vpon his shield, which lightly he did throw
To whom she did her liking lightly cast,
I lightly snatcht him vp, and with me bore away.
Is lightly stricken with some stones throw;
Therefore Sir Terpin from you lightly throw
She lightly to him leapt, and in his necke
But he him selfe full lightly from him freed,
Vnto a strangers loue so lightly placed,
He lightly reft his head, to ease him of his paine.
But he them all from him full lightly swept,
Might lightly fetch. But he was fierce and whot,
But he it seeing, lightly to him lept,
And therefore lightly bad him packe away,
Whose doome was death, but lightly slipping by,
He lightly started vp like one aghast,
For she of late is lightned of her wombe,
Ne lightned was with window, nor with louer,
Then lightnesse and inconstancie in loue;
Was lightnesse seene, or looser vanitie,
For feare she should of lightnesse be detected:
As where th'Almighties lightning brond does light,
Of lightning, through bright heauen fulmined;
Armd with his thunderbolts and lightning fire,
With dreadfull thunder and lightning atwixt,
And fire did flash, like lightning after thunder,
Like as the lightning brond from riuen skie,
And through her eyes like sudden lightning flashed,
